content:
To suppress scientific notation in a NumPy array when printing, you can use the `numpy.set_printoptions` function to control the formatting of your array output. By setting the `formatter` parameter, you can specify how to format floating-point numbers. Here's how you can do it:

```python
import numpy as np

my_list = [[3.74, 5162, 13683628846.64, 12783387559.86, 1.81],
           [9.55, 116, 189688622.37, 260332262.0, 1.97],
           [2.2, 768, 6004865.13, 5759960.98, 1.21],
           [3.74, 4062, 3263822121.39, 3066869087.9, 1.93],
           [1.91, 474, 44555062.72, 44555062.72, 0.41],
           [5.8, 5006, 8254968918.1, 7446788272.74, 3.25],
           [4.5, 7887, 30078971595.46, 27814989471.31, 2.18],
           [7.03, 116, 66252511.46, 81109291.0, 1.56],
           [6.52, 116, 47674230.76, 57686991.0, 1.43],
           [1.85, 623, 3002631.96, 2899484.08, 0.64],
           [13.76, 1227, 1737874137.5, 1446511574.32, 4.32],
           [13.76, 1227, 1737874137.5, 1446511574.32, 4.32]]

my_array = np.array(my_list)

# Set print options to suppress scientific notation
np.set_printoptions(suppress=True, formatter={'float_kind': '{:0.2f}'.format})

# Now print the array
print(my_array)
```

In this example, `np.set_printoptions(suppress=True)` is used to suppress scientific notation. The `formatter` option is set to format floating-point numbers to two decimal places. You can adjust `{:0.2f}` to your desired precision.
